en: Interview with Kendall Beals, PhD candidate with the Ecology and Evolutionary Biology department of UT. Beals discusses the impact that the wildfires had on the soil in the Smokey's. She also elaborates on the effects that high burn soil can have on flora in the area. This is a representative quote from the interview: "Fires aren't always bad for natural ecosystems, especially if they are more frequent and lower intensity. Wildfires like this where they're very hot, flames are really high, and it takes them a while to pass through systems are mostly detrimental."

Interview with Kendall Beals, 2019-11-09 -- Great Smoky Mountains National Park
How long have you lived in East Tennessee?
Can you tell us about your career path that brought you here?
What does your work look like at UT?
What are some personal interests or community involvement in east Tennessee?
Could you describe the focus of your research outside of the wildfires?
Could you talk about some of the conversations leading up to studying the fire's effects?
Can you talk about the different methodologies for your research and what the field research looked like?
What happens to the soil when you bring it back to the lab?
When did you first start going to the park for research?
What are some of the results you are seeing from your research?
What does the response in plants growing in high burn soil imply about the recovery in the high burn areas?
What is the wider context that your research can give to public understanding?
Is there anything else about your research or the fire that you would like to add?

seo.title: Interview with Kendall Beals, 2019-11-09 - Rising From the Ashes Oral Histories
